Award.AwardTitle: US-Turkey Workshop: Empowering Women in Industrial Engineering Academia - International Collaborations for Research and Education, Ankara, Turkey, March 2012
Award.AbstractNarration:
1042980
Smith

Description: This award is to support a US- Turkey workshop on Empowering Women in Industrial Engineering Academia, to be held in Istanbul, Turkey in March 2012. The organizers are Dr. Alice E. Smith, Department of Industrial Engineering (IE) at Auburn University, Auburn, Alabama and Dr. Dr. Zeki Ayag of Kadir Has University (KHU) in Istanbul, Turkey. The workshop builds upon a highly successful prior workshop held in Turkey in 2008. It allows broader participation by women from the Middle East, and provides emphasis on both research and teaching. There will be pre-workshop activities to help participants interact leading to a more productive and more effective meeting. A website will be developed to sustain the collaboration efforts. Significant support is provided by KHU for the logistics of the meeting. A planned tour at Mercedes-Benz facility in Turkey will provide a good perspective to the workshop participants as the majority of students that they mentor enter the field of industry as opposed to academia. Assessment of the workshop will occur at the conclusion of the workshop and 12-18 months afterward which will provide valuable insight.

Intellectual merit: Articulation of and answers to the issues surrounding international collaborations and advancement in industrial engineering academia from a female perspective is needed. From the U.S. perspective, insights and approaches can be learned from Middle Eastern counterparts, who for the most part are more progressive in recruiting and advancing women in engineering academia despite their more traditional cultural heritages. From the Middle Eastern perspective, participating successfully in the international scholarly research arena and enabling international collaborations are areas where benefits can be gained from the U.S. participants. IE research, practice and education would benefit greatly from having successful female role models in the field and internationally, and the linkage between research and teaching is essential for success in academia. Many of the richer and more interesting industrial engineering research topics such as sustainable engineering lend themselves to a broader, more international examination, and this workshop will help to facilitate this need.

Broader impacts: The workshop targets a very wide segment of industrial engineering women in academia from the U.S. and several Middle Eastern nations. Increasing the rate of female PhD production and recruitment into engineering would impact both engineering education and practice. The Turkish experience in terms of the fraction of female faculty is an interesting phenomenon and the creation of a strong education a research bond between US academics and their Turkish counterparts can encourage this development. The workshop will be an unusual opportunity for in depth interaction among the U.S. participants and Turkish and Middle Eastern academics, and will enhance future collaboration and sharing among the countries and will promote advancement of the important topic of women in engineering academia. This project is being funded by the Diversity and Outreach Prrogram in ENG and by the Office of International Science and Engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The workshop Women in Industrial Engineering Academia (WIEA) was held in Istanbul, Turkey from May 30 through June 1 of 2012.  There were 75 participants from nine countries.  These included 64 female and 11 male attendees with the top three countries of origin of attendees being the United States, Turkey and Iraq. Forty academic institutions were represented and the breakdown in career stage was 24% graduate student or post doctoral researcher, 32% assistant professor, 16% associate professor and 28% full professor.   The participants conducted pre-workshop virtual networking through the conference website.  This allowed them to identify others to target for development of research or educational interactions.

Workshop activities included a keynote address given by Dr. Jane Ammons of Georgia Institute of Technology, panel discussions, break out sessions, lunch meetings of small groups with similar research or educational interests, research and educational poster forums, and a technical tour of Mercedes Turkey.  The tour was structured to allow the WIEA attendees to interact with women engineers at the Mercedes plant.  There were also networking opportunities so that the participants could form long lasting relationships leading to future collaborations.

The feedback from the workshop was overwhelmingly positive and it is clear that the event, while only lasting a few days, was impactful on the lives of those who participanted, regardless of country of origin or career stage. Some comments from the participants' feedback are:

"This was the best IE conference that I have ever attended. Whenever people ask me “how was the Turkey conference?” I tell them that it was “life changing.” In terms of career preparation and developing expectations, nobody had been as willing to discuss the necessary truths about publishing, tenure, funding, and other tasks that are essential to success in IE academia. I believe most people that I spoke with prior to this conference made special effort to avoid the “taboo” topics, especially as they related to women’s issues. I am so grateful that I had this opportunity."

"This was one of the more memorable conferences I attended. I got to interact with many academics outside my immediate field and made some wonderful connections which will stay for life. The conference structure (with the technical material delivered via poster sessions, and issues such as career development and collaboration being addressed in panel discussions) was especially conducive for the purpose of the conference. The social events cemented the interaction among the attendees and were enjoyable as well as fruitful. All in all - it was a very worthwhile event and it has enriched me."

"Although I just started my academic career as a junior faculty, this is by far the greatest workshop I have ever attended. You will not able to learn how to do well as a women IE academician or to find international collaboration opportunities in other workshops or conferences."

"This workshop is one of the highlights of my academic career to-date and I feel so lucky to have attended."

"The small size of the workshop was really key to the experience. It made everyone much more accessible and you really got an opportunity to talk with people at different stages of their career and also from different backgrounds and cultures."
